msDesc.head: Anthology of Geoffrey Chaucer's literary works, with other texts

summary.seg: There are several reasons why MS Gg.4.27(1) (hereafter 'Gg') occupies a special place among early manuscript copies of Geoffrey Chaucer's writings. It has however seen some vicissitudes during its long life, which need to be mentioned. Compiled somewhere in East Anglia (probably not far east of Cambridge) a couple of decades or so after the poet's death in 1400, Gg constitutes the only surviving attempt to gather most of his poems between the covers of a single book, before collected editions of his works began to appear in print in the early 16th century. Like a few other Chaucer manuscripts, Gg was once extensively illustrated and decorated, but sadly most of the leaves carrying the artwork were cut out sometime during the sixteenth century, carrying away with them significant quantities of the text. Chaucer's language was by this time becoming increasingly difficult for readers to understand, especially so in the shape of the East Anglian dialect of Gg's main scribe, and the manuscript might well have been discarded or used as a source of scrap parchment, as was the fate of many other medieval books. Fortunately, in or around 1600, it was rescued by an Elizabethan antiquary named Joseph Holland, who set about rectifying some of the damage, and 'improving' the manuscript in other ways. Among other things, he commissioned replacement leaves to supply the parts of the text that had gone missing during the previous generation, together with a glossary, an engraved picture of Chaucer as a 'title page', and some account of the life of the poet. Most of these materials came from a new collected edition of Chaucer's works that had been published by Thomas Speght in 1598.

It was in this strange hybrid state that Gg reached the University Library, probably in 1664, as part of the collection of Richard Holdsworth, who had been Master of Emmanuel College. There it remained, relatively undisturbed, until the mid-19th century, when it came to the notice of Henry Bradshaw, at first a keeper of manuscripts and subsequently University Librarian, who possessed the distinction of being not only the most accomplished bibliographer of the time, but also its most knowledgeable student of Chaucer's writings. In 1865, Bradshaw decided to return Gg as far as possible to its original state. With great care and skill he disbound the manuscript, and removed the leaves inserted by Holland to the back of the book, establishing in the process its original construction, and the continuity of the texts. In addition, he brought to light various features of the book which have since further enhanced its interest and importance, notably the fact that it contains a unique revised version of one of Chaucer's most accomplished and characteristic poems, the Prologue to the Legend of Good Women; and, moreover, that it had originally included at least one full-page picture. It is thus essentially Bradshaw's reconstruction that we see when we open Gg.4.27(1) today.

These, and no doubt other episodes in Gg's chequered past, have effaced whatever evidence it might have contained as to who commissioned or compiled it, or who first owned it. It is however clear that, as an example of early 15th-century bookmaking, Gg stands apart from the London metropolitan book trade that produced the kind of up-market manuscripts in which Chaucer's writings were first transmitted, such as the Ellesmere Canterbury Tales (San Marino (CA), Huntington Library, MS EL 26 C 9) and the Corpus Troilus and Criseyde (Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 61). By contrast, art historians are of the opinion that Gg's illustrations are no less 'provincial' in style than the East Anglian dialect of its scribes. Whoever obtained the exemplars from which the latter worked seems to have been a resourceful and perhaps well-connected admirer of Chaucer whose aim was to preserve as far as possible his entire literary legacy. A separate copy of Chaucer's Treatise on the Astrolable (spotted by Bradshaw in Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS. e Mus. 116), which is also in the hand of Gg's main scribe, may have been part of the same campaign. Gg's unique copy of a revised version of the Prologue to the Legend of Good Women has been mentioned, and its texts of the Canterbury Tales and the Parlement of Foules have been judged especially important by modern editors. The only major work that eluded the compiler was the House of Fame, and the early version of John Lydgate's Temple of Glas (? c. 1420), included at the end of Gg, may have been intended as a substitute. The subject of the missing full-page picture that originally stood between the end of Gg's copy of Troilus and the beginning of the Canterbury Tales also invites speculation in this context. Might it have been another elaborate author portrait, similar to the celebrated frontispiece to the deluxe copy of Troilus and Criseyde at Corpus Christi College, affirming Chaucer's identity and status?

Whatever the precise motives underlying the compilation of Gg, it plays a significant role in the origins of a cultural tradition devoted to venerating Chaucer as the first recognisably great English author, and a distinct literary personality. Joseph Holland's early modern attempt to reconstitute the book as such speaks to this impulse, while two centuries or more later we find Henry Bradshaw industriously peeling away the later accretions and seeking to restore what is left of the original monument, as it were. Bradshaw's activities sparked an interest in the manuscript, which (as the accompanying bibliography shows) has continued actively down to the present day. Following in Bradshaw's wake, F.J. Furnivall swiftly printed most of the contents in his series of Chaucer Society publications during the latter half of the nineteenth century, and towards the end of the twentieth another landmark was reached when the entire manuscript was published in a three-volume photographic facsimile, with an elaborate descriptive introduction. The digital images furnished here constitute a further phase of development, and offer many avenues of enquiry for the future.

Richard Beadle
Professor of Medieval English Literature and Palaeography emeritus
St John's College, Cambridge

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

custEvent.p: By February 1866 at the latest, but probably not before November 1864, Henry Bradshaw had the leaves containing King Horn and other fragmentary Middle English texts removed from MS Gg.4.27. In his personal copy of the catalogue of manuscripts (now Cambridge, University Library, Adv.c.77.52), Bradshaw had noted against Gg.4.27, 'out on a bond 14th Novr 64'. Records of Bradshaw's borrowing of the manuscript are preserved in H.R. Luard, A chronological list of the graces, documents, and other papers in the University Registry which concern the University Library (Cambridge, 1870). Entries nos 755 and 760 confirm that by February 1866, the manuscript had been separated into two volumes thereafter referred to as 'MS Gg.4.27.1' and the King Horn leaves as 'MS Gg.4.27.2'. See: Beadle (2019) for further details. (The separation of the final running number by a full-stop reflects 19th- and early 20th-century practice, though brackets were also in use during this period and is the preferred approach today).

It is not certain at which date MS Gg.4.27(1) as a whole was disbound, but the likelihood is that it occurred around that same time. Bradshaw removed the leaves that Joseph Holland had added and assigned them a separate foliation sequence prefaced by an opening bracket '('. In the process of understanding the structure of the leaves of MS Gg.4.27(1), Bradshaw then added slips of paper to this volume, which he marked with the folio numbers of leaves that he judged to be missing.

It is unclear whether Henry Bradshaw had MS Gg.4.27(1) rebound during his lifetime or whether the manuscript was left unbound at the time of his death in 1886. Certainly, it was bound in 1896 by Stoakley (late Hawes) (see Binding for further details). These former covers are now preserved with the manuscript. At that juncture, the leaves that Holland had added and that Bradshaw had refoliated were bound in at the back of the manuscript.

During rebinding in 1997, a number of changes were made to MS Gg.4.27(1). The covers that had been added by Stoakley were removed and preserved. The leaves that had been added by Holland were removed and bound separately in a soft-cover parchment binding, and stored in a box marked 'MS Gg.4.27.1. Additional leaves'. The slips of paper that Bradshaw had added were also removed and preserved. In their place were added fresh sheets of parchment that signified missing or cancelled leaves (but see Foliation for further details). Mistakes in the ordering of the leaves that predated Stoakley's binding and Bradshaw's examination of the volume were also corrected, as follows:
Quire 16: 3rd and 11th leaves missing: their stubs were previously bound as the 2nd and 10th leaves (hence Bradshaw's initial misnumbering of f. 184 as '185', and f. 192 as '193').
Quire 22: 6th leaf missing: its stub was previously bound as the 7th leaf (hence Bradshaw's initial misnumbering of f. 261 as '260'.
The main part of MS Gg.4.27(1) was then fully rebound: full alum-tawed calf with jacket of the same material, by Jim Bloxam, Allan Farrant and Janet Coleby, Cambridge University Library, 1997.

extent.seg: 72 leaves of parchment have been inserted in place of missing and cancelled leaves as part of the volume's conservation (for further information on which, see Custodial History). These inserted leaves have been digitised and some of the stubs to which they are attached contain small fragments of text. These replacement leaves have not been counted here as part of the manuscript's extent. For the sake of clarity, it has been decided not to enumerate them separately either. iv + 454 + iv leaves.

note.p: Written in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the recto of each leaf by Henry BradshawBradshaw, Henry, 1831-1886, University Librarian 1867-1886. Bradshaw introduced the practice of assigning folio numbers to leaves that he judged to be missing on the basis of the manuscript's collation. Unfortunately, in the case of MS Gg.4.27(1), Bradshaw's interpretation of the structure of the manuscript's leaves in Quire 25 changed: having previously thought that one leaf was missing after f. 302v, he later decided that two leaves were missing. As a consequence, his first foliation sequence was thereafter cancelled and a second sequence added that differed from the first by 1. Some this second sequence has since been over-written by a later hand.

Although replacement leaves were added throughout the manuscript during its conservation, and although these technically carry a folio number (in accordance with Bradshaw's foliation practice), the foliation statement given above counts only medieval leaves and omits replacement leaves and stubs (see also Collation).

The leaves of parchment that have been inserted for missing leaves are: ff. 1-4, 12-13, 28-29, 54, 80-81, 102, 127-131, 142-144, 185, 193, 195, 211, 228, 233-234, 242-243, 260, 276, 285-286, 298-301, 303-304, 313, 318-320, 325-326, 350, 363-364, 372, 374, 383, 399-400, 405, 412, 418, 425, 428-429, 444, 469, 513, 517. The leaves of parchment that have been inserted for cancelled leaves are: ff. [109a], [118a], [123a], [123b], [430a], [430b], [493a], [508a], [515a]. As Parkes and Beadle (1979-80) explain (see vol. 3, p. 10), f. '444' is a questionable case. Bradshaw thought that a leaf was missing here, and thus assigned it a folio number: 'the recto could have contained the 'Retractions', and the verso would have been blank. However, the display at the foot of f. 443v could have been regarded as a colophon (the script is larger than that of other displayed headings and colophons in the Canterbury Tales...), in which case the leaf would have been blank'.
Blank, modern endleaves [ii]-[iv] and [v]-[vii] have not been digitised.

foliation.note: Written in black ink in the upper right-hand corner of the recto side of each leaf, after the insertion of replacement leaves of text (which are now bound separately as Cambridge, University Library, MS Gg.4.27, additional leaves), probably by Holland, Joseph, active 1585 Joseph Holland (d. 1605).

collation.p:
The manuscript comprises 43 quires, mostly of 12 leaves, all but 9 of which are now imperfect due to the excision of leaves that bore decoration, whether initials and borders or narrator portraits. Two quires - Quires 10 and 43 - are regular, though in both cases one bifolium is formed of two separate half-sheets. Although replacement leaves were added throughout the manuscript during its conservation, and although these technically carry a folio number (in accordance with Bradshaw's foliation practice), the collation statement given below counts only medieval leaves and omits replacement leaves and stubs (see also Foliation). For further discussion of anomalous quires, see Parkes and Beadle (1979-80), vol. 3, pp. 9-10, 39.

signatures.p: Leaf signatures added in the later 15th century (perhaps in place of an original sequence that had been lost to cropping; see Binding). The first signatures appear on Quire 2, 'a'; Quires 11-20 are signed 'a'-'i', but with 'k' on Quire 16 (without dislocation to the text). The other quires are signed by means of various symbols, and Quires 23 and 25 by numerical sequences only. (See Parkes and Beadle (1980), vol. 3, p. 63).

catchwords.seg: Catchwords by the main scribe, four of which have been lost to trimming and replaced, probably in the late 15th century (Quires 22, 25, 29 and 38). (See Parkes and Beadle (1979-80), vol. 3, p. 62).

supportDesc.condition: Many of the leaves bearing decoration - borders, initials and narrator portraits for the Canterbury Tales were mutilated at some point before the manuscript entered the possession of Joseph Holland in or around 1600 (see Provenance).

layout.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only, in single columns, 35-40 lines, written below top line.

handDesc.summary: The manuscript was copied by two scribes. Almost all of the volume was copied by one scribe (A). Only the final quire contains the work of both the main scribe and another (B). Importantly, a leaf copied by A is conjoint with a leaf copied by B, which indicates that - for this quire at least - the two were collaborating (rather than B providing replacements for leaves that had been copied by A and then discarded). Quotations in what follows are taken from Parkes and Beadle (1979-80), vol. 3, pp. 44, 46; further palaeographical analysis of scribal practices and orthography may be found therein (pp. 46-56), together with discussion of punctuation and abbreviation (pp. 56-57) and correction (p. 62).

handNote.p: Scribe A: Quires 1-42 (ff. 5-505) and part of Quire 43 (ff. 506r-507v, 511r-512v and 515r-516v only). 'For the text, Scribe A adopted a mixed hand: Anglicana Formata in aspect, but with forms and features derived from different scripts', including Bastard Secretary, Textura Semi-quadrata, and a range of scripts for display purposes, including Secretary and Textura. Scribe A also copied Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS e Musaeo 116, ff. 1r-56v.
Scribe B: part of Quire 43 (ff. 508r-510v and 514r-514v. Scribe B also wrote in Anglicana formata, but in a form distinct from that of Scribe A.

decoNote.p: ?Full-page miniature (?perhaps an author portrait), now missing except for small pieces of marginal decoration preserved on the remaining stub (f. 130v).

Miniatures to the Canterbury Tales: one-third to one-half of a page in size, in colours with flourished borders sketched roughly in ink (apparently by a later hand). Tales narrators are each shown mounted on a horse. Most of the miniatures have been lost (see f. 174v for an example). 'Representations of the pilgrims, portrait figures on horses, occur in other manuscripts of the Canterbury Tales, but only the Ellesmere and 'Oxford' manuscripts have analogues of the figures which survive in Gg...The three surviving representations of the Vices and Virtues are unique in surviving Chaucer manuscripts... The style of surviving pictures in Gg.4.27(1) suggests that there was probably more than one artist involved in the production of the manuscript' (Parkes and Beadle (1979-80), vol. 3, pp. 58-59). Ellesmere = California, San Marino, Huntington Library MS. El. 26 C 9. 'Oxford' = Manchester, John Rylands Library, MS English 63 + Philadelphia, Rosenbach Collection, MS 1084/2.
186r: Reeve
192v: Cook
222r: Wife of Bath
306r: Pardoner
352r: Monk
395r: Manciple
416r: Envy (astride a dog, handing it a bone); Charity (wearing triple-crowned tiara and holding a sceptre and flaming winged heart); outline sketch in orange crayon for crowned female figure in the gutter margin to the left of Envy
432r: Gluttony (astride a bear, holding a bird and a piece of rope); Abstinence (holding a lily in one hand and a jug in the other)
433r: Lechery (astride a ram, holding it by a horn with one hand, and bearing a bird with lock and chain in the other); Chastity

Blue or purple and rose initials, 4-8 lines, filled with blue, purple, rose and orange leaves (with occasional dragon grotesques), on gold ground (ff. 5r, 175r, 176r, 186v, 192r, 222v, 287r, 306r, 323r, 352r, 395r, 416v, 423v, 427v, 432r, 433r, 445r, 481r). Some have been excised (e.g. f. 359r).

Gold, blue and purple bar borders by two artists, extending from illuminated initials into vines with blue, purple, rose and orange leaves, gold discs, pen sprays and tendrils in one- or three-sided borders. Short sprays with gold discs, blue and purple leaves, extending from gold initials.
Further fragments survive on stubs of folios whose initials have been cut out (e.g. ff. 193r, 277r, 381r).

'The style of the surviving borders is archaic and reminiscent of English border decoration at the beginning of the fifteenth century, although the large motifs in the infilling of the accompanying initials is more appropriate to a later date.' (Parkes and Beadle (1979-80), vol. 3, p. 60).
Initials in gold, 3-4 lines, on blue and rose or orange and rose ground (ff. 259r, 281r).

Initials in blue, 2-6 lines, with infill and marginal flourishing in red ink, some containing faces within the interstices (e.g. ff. 93v, 112r, 349v, 454r, 478v) or human heads or animal heads sprouting from the sides of the initials (e.g. human heads on ff. 10v, 336r, 345v; animal heads on ff. 333v, 478v).
Grotesques and profiles by the scribe extending from calligraphic letters, and sometimes touched in red (e.g. ff. 480v, 512r).

note.p: Rubrics added in a variety of coloured inks by a late 16th-/early 17th-century hand, commissioned by the manuscript's then owner, the antiquary Joseph Holland (d. 1605). See: ff. 5r, 194v, 275v, 284v, 297v, 312v, 317v, 362v, 371v, 398v, 443v, 453v, 456v, 462v, 466v, 474r, 476v, 478v. This scribe's work is evident in other manuscripts owned by Holland: see, for example, London, British Library, Cotton MS Vespasian E V, f. 18r and London, British Library, Harley MS 7026, throughout.

These rubrics relate to the text that Holland instructed to be copied onto the replacement leaves he had added to the volume, along with other matter relating to Chaucer or the text, some of which was taken from an edition of Chaucer's works published in 1598 by Thomas Speght. These leaves were originally bound in at the relevant places in the manuscript. For the subsequent rearrangement of the manuscript and the placement of these leaves, see Custodial History. These leaves are described below in Part 2, with digital images following those of the main volume, here described as Part 1.
For further discussion of the material added by Joseph Holland, see Parkes and Beadle (1979-80), vol. 3, pp. 65-66.

The manuscript also contains Holland's distinctive annotation mark (a curved line above two dots) against references in the text to various items of apparent interest:
f. 145r (a statue of Mars)
f. 166v (a herald)
f. 171r (the funeral of Arcite)
f. 213v (a local custom, the Dunmow Flitch)
f. 448v (the size of Chaucer's library)
f. 397v ('Ne tellyth neuere no man In Èoure lyf...')
f. 481r ('For ofte of olde feldys as men sey...')
Holland was apparently responsible for having this manuscript bound together with what is now MS Gg.4.27(2), which also contains his annotation mark on f. 10r.

Leaf signatures added by Henry BradshawBradshaw, Henry, 1831-1886: written in pencil in the lower right-hand corner of the rectos, in the first half of each quire; '+' marks the first leaf of the second half of the quire. The sequence is a-k (Quires 1-10), A-Z (Quires 11-33) and Aa-Kk (Quires 34-43). It is unclear what Bradshaw intended to signify by the choice of different sequences of letter, since these do not coincide with changes in page preparation, scribal hand or other element of production, nor with changes in the textual contents.

Henry BradshawBradshaw, Henry, 1831-1886 also made numerous annotations in pencil throughout the manuscript, identifying line and stanza numbers, as well as marking where the text had been disturbed (see ff. 112v, 349r, 450r-450v).
Further notes in pencil and ink, probably by Henry BradshawBradshaw, Henry, 1831-1886, on the pastedown and front endleaf of the 19th-century binding.

binding.p: Full alum-tawed calf with jacket of the same material, bound by Jim Bloxam, Allan Farrant and Janet Coleby, Cambridge University Library, 1997. See Custodial History for further information.

Bound in 1896 by Stoakley (late Hawes). Half bound brown pigskin with marbled paper sides. Mould-made paper ends. Sewn on five double cords. Turquoise, red and white endbands. Lower edge of both boards badly worn (from Cambridge University Library Conservation Report, 1997). This former binding has been retained and is stored with the manuscript.
Apparently rebound and the edges trimmed at some point in the later fifteenth century, based on the loss of catchwords to Quires 22, 25, 29 and 37, and their replacement by a hand of this period.

origin.origDate: Early 15th century (as dated by Parkes and Beadle (1979-80) and Connolly (2009); Binski and Zutshi (2011) suggest c. 1420-c. 1430).

provenance.p: 5r, 516v: 'Ioseph Holland 1600'. Ownership inscription of Holland, Joseph, active 1585 Joseph Holland (d. 1605) , antiquary (inscription now erased but located directly beneath the Cambridge University Library stamp in the lower margin, and still visible under UV light). (See also Additions).

Apparently consulted by John Stow Stow, John, 1525?-1605, antiquary: in the copy of the Temple of Glass in Oxford, Bodleian Library, MS Fairfax 16 (f. 82v), Stow noted: 'Here lacketh .6. leves that are in Joseph Holland's Boke'.
Perhaps consulted by Thomas Speght (d. 1621)Speght, Thomas, -1621, printer, prior to printing 'Chaucer's ABC' in his edition of 1602 (see Pace (1968)).
Almost certainly one of the manuscripts of Richard Holdsworth (1590-1649), Master of Emmanuel College Holdsworth, Richard, 1590-1649.

history.acquisition: Acquired by the University Library in July 1664. Probably no. 51 in the inventory of Holdsworth's manuscripts compiled by William Crowe (MS Ff.4.27 / Dd.8.45).

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the recto side of each leaf, by Henry BradshawBradshaw, Henry, 1831-1886, University Librarian 1867-1886.

Written in black ink in the upper right-hand corner of the recto side of each leaf, according to the original position of leaves added to Part 1 in order to supply missing text or supplement the contents of the manuscript, probably by Holland, Joseph, active 1585 Joseph Holland (d. 1605) .

supportDesc.condition: Losses to the edges and corners of ff. (1 and (2.

layout.seg: Highly variable layout, with text copied by several different hands and to different specifications. Leaves supplying text lost from Chaucer are written in single columns, usually ruled in leadpoint, written above top line. Glossary in three columns.

handNote.p: Folios (1v, (2v, (4v-(22v, (29v and (35r copied in Humanistic cursive script by a late 16th-/early 17th-century hand, commissioned by the manuscript's then owner, the antiquary Joseph Holland (d. 1605). This hand was also responsible for copying in rubrics in a variety of coloured inks: see Part 1, Additions, for further details. This scribe's work is evident in other manuscripts owned by Holland: see, for example, London, British Library, Cotton MS Vespasian E V, f. 18r and London, British Library, Harley MS 7026, throughout. Perhaps the same hand or another writing in the same script also copied parts of the Glossary on ff. (30r-(32v.

Folios (23r-(28v copied in Secretary script by a late 16th-/early 17th-century hand, also commissioned by the manuscript's then owner, the antiquary Joseph Holland (d. 1605). Perhaps the same hand or another writing in the same script also copied ff. (33r-(34v and parts of the Glossary on ff. (30r-(32v.

decoNote.p: Engraved portrait of Chaucer, surrounded by a genealogical diagram illustrating his parentage, descendants and relations, and showing his tomb, coloured by hand (f. (3r. Taken from a copy of Speght's 1598 edition of Chaucer's works.

note.p: Folio 2r: note concerning the position of leaves now bound separately as MS Gg.4.27(2), by 'J.M.K.' - i.e. John Mitchell Kemble (1807-1857)Kemble, John M. (John Mitchell), 1807-1857: 'Note: After p. 482b of this volume are inserted fourteen folios on parchment, containing a fine copy of the fragment of Floriz and Blaunchefleur, a copy of King Horn and a poem on the assumption of our Lady. To the best of my knowledge these have never been noticed. J.M.K.'

binding.p: A softcover parchment binding, by Jim Bloxam, Allan Farrant and Janet Coleby, Cambridge University Library, 1997. See Custodial History for further information.

Turquoise, red and white endbands. Lower edge of both boards badly worn (from Cambridge University Library Conservation Report, 1997). This former binding has been retained and is stored with the manuscript.

origin.p: The leaves comprising Part 2 were commissioned by the antiquary Joseph Holland (d. 1605) and were for the most part copied from Thomas Speght's 1598 edition of Chaucer's works.
